No, I'm not leaving twitter. But I'm not using it like I used to, either. Because so many of you have gone quiet, and because there's now so much damn noise.

Yes, social media needs to evolve. It took us to a terrible place after taking us to a wonderful place.

- And we'll be right back here (though not ~here~ since Twitter won't exist) in roughly 10 years, having some flavor of this conversation again. Likely without the E-word, but with a person or entity that is just as polarizing.

- New forms of spam will be created
- New types of misinformation will be invented and spread
- Algorithmic curation will eventually be required ‚Äì it'll be too hard to manually moderate all the instances and users and what start out as benevolent bots

- We will wind up with just a few power brokers (as we always do)
- They will hold majority marketshare (Google started out "not evil," gmail was for progressive, tech-forward kids, remember?)
- Regulators will show up late to the party, complaining

This is what happens next: 

- We'll disburse to federated systems
- It'll take time for people to find their places
- Many new #failwhales across ecosystems
- Mainstream users will be initially left out, then will join
- Consolidation will follow (as it always, always does)

So in the video (above), I explain why I think the car guy is intentionally killing the site. A week later, with all the events that've transpired, it looks like I'm right.

Which again, sucks.

I think the E-word is quiet quitting Twitter. I explain why starting at 38:00 in this video. I'd just returned from a challenging hike & backcountry camping trip on the AT and was tired. I remember thinking after we wrapped that I hoped I was wrong.

https://t.co/D9OUCkMriR

I don't think there's a realistic long-term success scenario for Twitter. I don't see growth. I don't even see survivability.

And I think that was the new owner's plan. I think he's intentionally killing it, in a way that makes bankruptcy legitimate. 

Which sucks.

Maybe it's because I've been mainlining Radiohead all morning and that tends to put me in a ~mood~ or maybe it's because I miss my twitter friends and their random links and feeling like I have lines of sight into a million different horizons, but I'm pissed about the present.

Twitter's leaders should have taken steps to monetize early on. They should have built scenarios showing various futures for the tech stack and business. I know why they didn't and to this day I'll continue to argue that they should have done real, long-range strategic planning.

I've been on this damn site since its earliest twttr days. I used the old SMS service. My daughter had a fail whale onesie ‚Äì she's about to turn 13. I remember NPR anchors making fun of twitter on air rather than embracing change and evolving.

Yes, Twitter's firehose is quickly becoming a cesspool of airdrop bros/ bots and it's disintegrating into an apocalyptic hellscape of -isms (racism, antisemitism, etc). But at some point, that firehose was useful for discoverability -- in a good way.

I can manually look around the internet for (in this case) ukiyo-e, or join a mastodon instance (probably?) or discord. But I wound up following @artistKuniyoshi accidentally, because I saw it pop up in another user's feed.

The thing I'm going to miss about twitter is the serendipity. Yes, there's a bunch of shit on the site now, but I'm going to miss the accounts that deliver interesting content that help me learn something new, see a different perspective, or otherwise delight me during the day.

This is a tragedy of the commons case study (sort of).  

The communications space we evolved to -- email -- uses protocols and infrastructure required by all. And it's poisoned. The power brokers shifted. It's free to send as much spam as you want. Email is a problem.

The internet made information theoretically free but gave the advantage to brokers and aggregators.

The White/ Yellow pages democratized information. Anyone who needed to find anyone could, and pretty easily.
